title: 104_hr2083
content: The Act titled "Tax Reduction and Economic Growth Act of 1995" allows for tax reduction in the event of low growth. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must notify the President and Congress if economic growth is below 1.5% and national unemployment is above 6.5% for specific testing periods. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must notify the President and Congress if economic growth is below 1.5% and national unemployment is above 6.5% for specific testing periods. After notification, the President may declare temporary income tax reductions for a specified calendar year to stimulate the economy. After notification from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget regarding low economic growth and high unemployment, the President can issue a declaration for temporary income tax reductions to provide a quick fiscal stimulus to the economy for a specified calendar year. This declaration must be transmitted to Congress, and if approved, temporary tax modifications will be effective for taxable years beginning in the specified calendar year. The President can issue a declaration for temporary income tax reductions after notification from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget regarding low economic growth and high unemployment. This declaration, once approved by Congress, will reduce the rates applicable to the first income bracket in the tax tables by up to 3 percent and adjust the tax amounts accordingly for taxable years beginning in the specified calendar year. The President can issue a declaration for temporary income tax reductions after notification from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget regarding low economic growth and high unemployment. The tax tables will be adjusted to reflect the rate reduction, and withholding procedures will be modified to ensure the full calendar year effect of the reduction is reflected. If economic growth requirements are subsequently satisfied, a temporary surtax may be implemented for taxable years beginning in the first subsequent calendar year. The President can declare temporary income tax reductions based on economic conditions. If economic growth requirements are met, a temporary surtax may be imposed in the following calendar year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 may increase tax rates by a certain percentage each year, except for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income below $50,000 and joint filers below $75,000. Tax rates for them should not exceed the previous year's rates. Adjustments to withholding taxes will also be made accordingly. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for annual tax rate increases, with exceptions for lower income individuals. Withholding taxes will be adjusted to reflect these rate changes. Economic growth requirements must be met for each calendar year. The tax rates are modified to reflect an increase, with economic growth requirements needing to be met each calendar year. The President must determine if GDP growth is over 4.5% and national unemployment is below 5.5%. The tax rate increase percentage is based on these factors. The real GDP is estimated to be over 4.5%, and national unemployment is estimated to be below 5.5%. The tax rate increase percentage is based on these factors without raising taxes for certain income brackets. The tax rate for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income below $50,000 and joint filers below $75,000 will not increase despite a decrease in receipts under the Code. The percentage will be published in the Federal Register before the start of the relevant calendar year. SEC. 3. Treatment under pay-as-you-go procedures: Any changes in receipts from the Act will not affect the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
